studyLevel1.title: Experiment X2 Traffic Complexity
studyLevel1.shortDescription: Evaluates whether increasing visual complexity of the driving environment affect's driver alertness and its regression-based estimation.
studyLevel1.description: Purpose: The purpose of this study was to evaluate whether increasing visual complexity of the driving environment (i.e., human and vehicle traffic events in same or opposite direction of subject vehicleâ€™s direction of travel) would affect driver alertness and whether the same basic regression-based approach would still enable performance prediction (Lin et al., 2005a,b). Methods Subjects: N volunteers from the local community (primarily local college students) Apparatus: Driving simulator with steering wheel and brake / foot pedals (Real Time Technologies; Dearborn, MI); Video Refresh Rate (VRR) = 900 Hz; Vehicle data log file Sampling Rate (SR) = 100 Hz); EEG (Biosemi 64 (+8) channel system with 4 eye and 2 mastoid channels recorded; SR=2048 Hz); Eye Tracking (Sensomotoric Instruments (SMI); REDEYE250) Procedures: Upon arrival to the lab, subjects were given an introduction to the study and provided informed consent and provided demographics information. They then practiced the driving task for 10-15 min until asymptotic performance in steering and speed control was demonstrated and lack of motion sickness was reported. Subjects were then outfitted and prepped for eye tracking and EEG acquisition. The first condition in this experiment was always the 15-min Cal condition, which consisted of a 15-min drive at a constant 45-mph (automated speed control) with vehicle perturbation forces imposed at a rate of 8-10 sec. Following completion of the Cal condition, subjects answered three questionnaires (see Dependent Variables below) and proceeded to complete the Baseline (BL) and Traffic Complexity (TC) conditions, both of which consisted of a 45-min drive at a subject-controlled speed limit of 45-mph (manual speed control). Two additional factors were incorporated into this experiment within conditions: (1) perturbation rates (Low [every 24-30s] vs. High [every 8-10s]) were manipulated in both BL and TC conditions and (2) traffic complexity (Low [vehicles and pedestrians presented every 8-10 s in various cluster sizes [1-6] vs. High [vehicles and pedestrians presented every 24-30 s in various cluster sizes [1-6]) in the TC condition. The order of presentation of BL and TC conditions were counterbalanced, as were perturbation rates and traffic complexity levels. The same three questionnaires were given between BL and TC conditions. In addition, the KSS was given verbally over the intercom at 15-min intervals in both BL and TC conditions.
